# Draft:Raousset's Expeditions into Sonora

Mexico
| combatant2        =  Filibusters
}}
The '''Raousset's Expeditions into Sonora' were attempts by French Filibuster Gaston de Raousset-Boulbon to invade the Mexican state of Sonora and declare it an independent country.
Two expeditions were made, one in 1852 which failed and resulted in the expulsion of his forces to San Francisco, California, and another one in 1854 which resulted in the Battle of Guaymas, and death of Raousset.
Background
Mexico was experiencing many problems and internal conflicts during the period of the Second Federal Republic, especially after the Mexican-American War, when the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo was signed. The period of the Second Federal Republic was one of the most eventful in Mexican history. With the loss of a war to the United States, constitutional change, and a civil war. It was also a period of Mexican political evolution experiencing the downfall of the Conservative Party that had predominated during the Centralist Republic, and marking the rise of the Liberal Party.
Gaston de Raousset-Boulbon was a Frenchman and theoretician of colonialism. After a series of failed enterprises as a gold prospector he became involved in a conflict in the Mexican state of Sonora. He embarked in 1850 for the Americas as a third-class passenger, and when the ship stopped in a Colombian port, and had sad impressions of the situation there. He wrote to a friend:
"At last, we're in the real America, Spanish America. Ruins, beggars, racial degradation, the random mixing of all bloodlines, guitar-playing bums... naked children, young savages running around among the dogs... and all in a wonderful natural setting.''"
